articles.title: Short title, extent, application and commencement

clauses.clause_text: This Act may be called the Prevention of Electronic Crimes Act, 2016.
It extends to the whole of Pakistan.
It shall apply to every citizen of Pakistan wherever he may be and also to every other person for the time being in Pakistan.

It shall also apply to any act committed outside Pakistan by any person if the act constitutes an offence under this Act and affects a person, property, information system or data located in Pakistan.
It shall come into force at once.

content.introductory_text: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context:

clauses.clause_text: “act” includes:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: a series of acts or omissions contrary to the provisions of this Act;

causing an act to be done by a person either directly or through an automated information system or automated mechanism or self-executing, adaptive or autonomous device and whether having temporary or permanent impact;

clauses.clause_text: “access to data” means gaining control or ability to use, copy, modify or delete any data held in or generated by any device or information system;
“access to information system” means gaining control or ability to use any part or whole of an information system whether or not through infringing any security measure;
“Authority” means the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority established under the Pakistan Telecommunication (Re-organization) Act, 1996 (XVII of 1996);
“authorization” means authorization by law or by the person empowered to make such authorization under the law:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: that where an information system or data is available for open access by the general public, access to or transmission of such information system or data shall be deemed to be authorized for the purposes of this Act.

clauses.clause_text: “authorized officer” means an officer of the investigation agency authorized to perform any function on behalf of the investigation agency by or under this Act;
"child" means a person below the age of eighteen years;

"child sexual abuse content" means the representation, by whatever means, of a child engaged in real or simulated sexually explicit conduct or representation of the sexual parts of a child for primarily sexual purposes;
“Code” means the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898);

"complainant" means any person who makes complaints of any offence under this Act and includes a victim or an individual having substantial reasons to believe the offence is being committed or likely to be committed and any authority referring the complaint for investigation;

“content data” means any representation of fact, information or concept for processing in an information system including source code or a program suitable to cause an information system to perform a function;
“Court” means the Court of competent jurisdiction designated under this Act;
“critical infrastructure” means critical elements of infrastructure namely assets, facilities, systems, networks or processes the loss or compromise of which could result in:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: major detrimental impact on the availability, integrity or delivery of essential services including those services, whose integrity, if compromised, could result in significant loss of life or casualties, taking into account significant economic or social impacts;

significant impact on national security, national defense, or the functioning of the state: Provided that the Government may designate any private or Government infrastructure in accordance with the objectives of sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii) above, as critical infrastructure as may be prescribed under this Act;

clauses.clause_text: “critical infrastructure information system or data” means an information system, program or data that supports or performs a function with respect to a critical infrastructure;

“damage to an information system” means any unauthorized change in the ordinary working of an information system that impairs its performance, access, output or change in location whether temporary or permanent and with or without causing any change in the system;
“data” includes content data and traffic data;
“data damage” means alteration, deletion, deterioration, erasure, relocation, suppression of data or making data temporarily or permanently unavailable;
“device” includes:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: physical device or article;
any electronic or virtual tool that is not in physical form;
a password, access code or similar data, in electronic or other form, by which the whole or any part of an information system is capable of being accessed;
automated, self-executing, adaptive or autonomous devices, programs or information systems;

clauses.clause_text: “dishonest intention” means intention to cause injury, wrongful gain or wrongful loss or harm to any person or to create hatred or incitement to violence;
“electronic” includes electrical, digital, magnetic, optical, biometric, electrochemical, electromechanical, wireless or electromagnetic technology;
“identity information” means an information which may authenticate or identify an individual or an information system and enable access to any data or information system;

“information” includes text, message, data, voice, sound, database, video, signals, software, computer programmes, any forms of intelligence as defined under the Pakistan Telecommunication (Reorganization) Act, 1996 (XVII of 1996) and codes including object code and source code;
“information system” means an electronic system for creating, generating, sending, receiving, storing, reproducing, displaying, recording or processing any information;

“integrity” means, in relation to an electronic document, electronic signature or advanced electronic signature, the electronic document, electronic signature or advanced electronic signature that has not been tampered with, altered or modified since a particular point in time;

“interference with information system or data” means and includes an unauthorized act in relation to an information system or data that may disturb its normal working or form with or without causing any actual damage to such system or data;
“investigation agency” means the law enforcement agency established by or designated under this Act;
“minor” means, notwithstanding anything contained in any other law, any person who has not completed the age of eighteen years;

“offence” means an offence punishable under this Act except when committed by a person under ten years of age or by a person above ten years of age and under fourteen years of age, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion;
“rules” means rules made under this Act;
“seize” with respect to an information system or data includes taking possession of such system or data or making and retaining a copy of the data;

"sexually explicit conduct" means actual or simulated sexual intercourse, including genital-genital, oral-genital, anal-genital, or oral-anal, whether between persons of the same or opposite sex; or (a) bestiality; or (b) masturbation; or (c) sadistic or masochistic abuse; or (d) lascivious exhibition of the anus, genitals, or pubic area of any person;
“service provider” includes a person who:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: acts as a service provider in relation to sending, receiving, storing, processing or distribution of any electronic communication or the provision of other services in relation to electronic communication through an information system;
owns, possesses, operates, manages or controls a public switched network or provides telecommunication services;
processes or stores data on behalf of such electronic communication service or users of such service;

clauses.clause_text: "sexual abuse of a minor" shall have the same meaning given to "sexual abuse" in section 377A of the Pakistan Penal Code (Act XLV of 1860);
“subscriber information” means any information held in any form by a service provider relating to a subscriber other than traffic data;
“traffic data” includes data relating to a communication indicating its origin, destination, route, time, size, duration or type of service;

“unauthorized access” means access to an information system or data which is not available for access by general public, without authorization or in violation of the terms and conditions of the authorization;
“unauthorized interception” shall mean in relation to an information system or data, any interception without authorization;

“unsolicited information” means the information which is sent for commercial and marketing purposes against explicit rejection of the recipient and does not include marketing authorized under the law.

Unless the context provides otherwise, any other expression used in this Act or rules made thereunder but not defined in this Act, shall have the same meanings assigned to the expressions in the Pakistan Penal Code, 1860 (Act XLV of 1860), the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898) and the Qanoon-e-Shahadat, 1984 (P.O.No.X of 1984), as the case may be.

articles.title: Unauthorized access to information system or data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention gains unauthorized access to any information system or data shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand rupees or with both.

articles.title: Unauthorized copying or transmission of data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention and without authorization copies or otherwise transmits or causes to be transmitted any data shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one hundred thousand rupees or with both.

articles.title: Interference with information system or data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention interferes with or damages or causes to be interfered with or damages any part or whole of an information system or data shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to two years or with fine which may extend to five hundred thousand rupees or with both.

articles.title: Unauthorized access to critical infrastructure information system or data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention gains unauthorized access to any critical infrastructure information system or data shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years or with fine which may extend to one million rupees or with both.

articles.title: Unauthorized copying or transmission of critical infrastructure data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention and without authorization copies or otherwise transmits or causes to be transmitted any critical infrastructure data shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine which may extend to five million rupees or with both.

articles.title: Interference with critical infrastructure information system or data

clauses.clause_text: Whoever with dishonest intention interferes with or damages, or causes to be interfered with or damaged, any part or whole of a critical information system, or data, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to seven years or with fine which may extend to ten million rupees or with both.

Whoever prepares or disseminates information, through any information system or device, with the intent to glorify an offence relating to terrorism, or any person convicted of a crime relating to terrorism, or activities of proscribed organizations or individuals or groups shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine which may extend to ten million rupees or with both.
For the purposes of this section 'glorification' includes depiction of any form of praise or celebration in a desirable manner.
Whoever commits or threatens to commit any of the offences under sections 6, 7, 8 or 9, where the commission or threat is with the intent to—

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: coerce, intimidate, create a sense of fear, panic or insecurity in the Government or the public or a section of the public or community or sect or create a sense of fear or insecurity in society;
advance inter-faith, sectarian or ethnic hatred;
advance the objectives of organizations or individuals or groups proscribed under the law,

content.punishment: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to fourteen years or with fine which may extend to fifty million rupees or with both.

clauses.clause_text: Whoever prepares or disseminates information, through any information system or device, that advances or is likely to advance interfaith, sectarian or racial hatred, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine or with both.

articles.title: Recruitment, funding and planning of terrorism

clauses.clause_text: Whoever prepares or disseminates information, through any information system or device, that invites or motivates to fund, or recruits people for terrorism or plans for terrorism shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine or with both.

Whoever interferes with or uses any information system, device or data, with the intent to cause damage or injury to the public or to any person, or to make any illegal claim or title or to cause any person to part with property or to enter into any express or implied contract, or with intent to commit fraud by any input, alteration, deletion, or suppression of data, resulting in unauthentic data with the intent that it be considered or acted upon for legal purposes as if it were authentic, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to two hundred and fifty thousand rupees or with both.

Whoever commits offence under sub-section (1) in relation to a critical infrastructure information system or data shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years or with fine which may extend to five million rupees or with both.

Whoever with the intent for wrongful gain interferes with or uses any information system, device or data or induces any person to enter into a relationship or deceives any person, which act or omission is likely to cause damage or harm to that person or any other person shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years or with fine which may extend to ten million rupees or with both.

articles.title: Making, obtaining, or supplying device for use in offence

clauses.clause_text: Whoever produces, makes, generates, adapts, exports, supplies, offers to supply or imports for use any information system, data or device, with the intent to be used or believing that it is primarily to be used to commit or to assist in the commission of an offence under this Act shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand rupees or with both.

Whoever obtains, sells, possesses, transmits or uses another person’s identity information without authorization shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years or with fine which may extend to five million rupees, or with both.

Any person whose identity information is obtained, sold, possessed, used or transmitted may apply to the Authority for securing, destroying, blocking access or preventing transmission of such identity information and the Authority may take appropriate measures for securing or destroying it.

articles.title: Unauthorized issuance of SIM cards etc.

clauses.clause_text: Whoever sells or otherwise provides subscriber identity module (SIM), re-usable identification module (R-IUM) or universal integrated circuit card (UICC) or other module designed for authenticating users to establish connection with the network without obtaining and verification of the subscriber’s antecedents in the manner approved by the Authority shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years or with fine which may extend to five hundred thousand rupees or with both.

Whoever unlawfully or without authorization changes, alters, tampers with or re-programs unique device identifier of any communication equipment including a cellular or wireless handset and starts using or marketing such device for transmitting and receiving information shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years or with fine which may extend to one million rupees or with both.
A 'unique device identifier' is an electronic equipment identifier which is unique to a communication device.
any transmission that is not intended to be and is not open to the public, from or within an information system;
electromagnetic emissions from an information system that are carrying data.

content.punishment: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years or with fine which may extend to five hundred thousand rupees or with both.

articles.title: Offences against dignity of a natural person

clauses.clause_text: Whoever intentionally and publicly exhibits or displays or transmits any information through any information system, which he knows to be false, and intimidates or harms the reputation or privacy of a natural person, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years or with fine which may extend to one million rupees or with both.

Any aggrieved person or his guardian, where such person is a minor, may apply to the Authority for removal, destruction of or blocking access to such information and the Authority shall pass appropriate orders.

articles.title: Offences against modesty of a natural person and minor

clauses.clause_text: Whoever intentionally and publicly exhibits or transmits any sexually explicit information or imagery that harms or blackmails a person shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years or with fine which may extend to five million rupees or with both.
If the offence under sub-section (1) is committed with respect to a minor, punishment shall extend to seven years and fine up to five million rupees; repeat offenders up to ten years.
The Authority shall act upon complaint of aggrieved person or guardian to remove, destroy or block access to such content.

Whoever intentionally produces, offers, makes available, distributes, transmits, procures, or possesses material depicting a minor in sexually explicit conduct shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to fourteen years and up to twenty years, and fine not less than one million rupees.
The Authority may remove, destroy, or block access to such content upon complaint by aggrieved person or guardian.

content.source: PEC2016.pdf, Section 22 (as amended by Fed. Act. No. XXXVII of 2023)

articles.title: Online grooming, solicitation and cyber enticement

clauses.clause_text: Whoever intentionally creates or takes steps towards creating a relationship of trust with a minor through an information system with the intent to facilitate or solicit sexual abuse shall be punished with imprisonment up to ten years (not less than five years) and fine up to ten million rupees.

content.source: Inserted by Fed. Act. No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: Whoever uses information systems for child prostitution, child sex tourism or sexual exploitation of minors shall be punished with imprisonment not less than fourteen years and up to twenty years and fine not less than one million rupees.

content.source: Inserted by Fed. Act. No. XXXVII of 2023

articles.title: Use of information system for kidnapping, abduction or trafficking of minor

clauses.clause_text: Whoever contacts a minor through an information system with intent to kidnap, abduct or traffic a minor shall be punished with imprisonment not less than fourteen years and up to twenty years and fine not less than one million rupees.

content.source: Inserted by Fed. Act. No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: Whoever willfully and without authorization writes, offers, makes available, distributes or transmits malicious code through an information system or device with intent to cause harm shall be punished with imprisonment up to two years or with fine up to one million rupees or both.
‘Malicious code’ includes a computer program or hidden function that damages or compromises an information system or data.

A person commits the offence of cyber stalking who, with the intent to coerce, intimidate or harass any person, uses information systems, the internet, or other electronic communication to repeatedly contact or monitor such person.
Punishable with imprisonment up to three years or fine up to one million rupees or both; if victim is a minor, punishment extends to five years and fine up to ten million rupees.
Aggrieved person or guardian may request Authority to remove or block such content.
A person commits cyberbullying who, with intent to harass, threaten or target another, posts or sends electronic messages, pictures or videos through social media platforms.
Child cyberbullying shall be punished with imprisonment up to five years but not less than one year and fine between one hundred thousand and five hundred thousand rupees.

content.source: Inserted by Fed. Act. No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: A person commits the offence of spamming who intentionally transmits harmful, fraudulent, misleading, illegal or unsolicited information to any person without permission.
Transmitting harmful or illegal spam: imprisonment up to three months or fine between fifty thousand and five million rupees or both.
Unsolicited marketing without opt-out: fine up to fifty thousand rupees for first offence, up to one million for repeated offences.
Whoever with dishonest intention establishes a website or sends information with a counterfeit source intended to deceive recipients commits spoofing.
Punishable with imprisonment up to three years or fine up to five hundred thousand rupees or both.

articles.title: Legal recognition of offences committed in relation to information system

clauses.clause_text: An offence shall not be denied legal recognition solely because it was committed through an information system.
References to ‘property’ in any law shall include information systems and data.
The provisions of the Pakistan Penal Code, 1860 apply to offences under this Act to the extent not inconsistent with this Act.

CHAPTER III.chapter_title: ESTABLISHMENT OF INVESTIGATION AGENCY AND PROCEDURAL POWERS FOR INVESTIGATION

clauses.clause_text: The Federal Government may establish or designate a law enforcement agency as the investigation agency for the purposes of investigation of offences under this Act.
Unless otherwise provided, the investigation agency and its officers shall follow the procedure laid down in the Code to the extent that it is not inconsistent with any provision of this Act.
The investigation agency shall establish its own capacity for forensic analysis of data and reports generated by it shall not be inadmissible merely for being prepared by the agency.

The Federal Government shall make rules for appointment, promotion and specialized training in digital forensics, IT, computer science and related areas for officers and staff of the investigation agency.

In addition to the Federal Investigation Agency, the Police shall be authorized to take cognizance of offences under this Act, but must refer the matter to FIA for technical opinion and investigation.
An investigating officer shall not be below the rank of Inspector or equivalent; if a Joint Investigation Team (JIT) is constituted, it shall be headed by a BS-18 officer and comprise five members.
The investigating officer or JIT shall complete the investigation within forty-five working days.
Courts shall proceed with trials weekly and decide cases within three months; delays must be reported to the Chief Justice of the concerned High Court for directions.

content.amendment: Substituted by Sec. 6 of Fed. Act No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: An investigating officer must produce the accused before the Court within 24 hours of arrest and may apply for remand not exceeding fourteen days at one time.

No extension of remand shall be allowed unless the Court is satisfied further evidence may be available and that no bodily harm has been caused or will be caused to the accused. Total remand period shall not exceed thirty days.
The Court shall be deemed to be a Magistrate for purposes of remand under sub-section (2).

content.source: Inserted by S.7 of Fed. Act No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: Federal and Provincial Governments shall establish a victim and witness protection system with provisions including security arrangements, identity concealment, distance recording, relocation, financial assistance, and safe houses.
Until rules are made, the Witness Protection, Security and Benefit Act, 2017 shall apply mutatis mutandis to victims and witnesses under this Act.

content.source: Inserted by S.7 of Fed. Act No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: Trials of offences against minors shall be conducted in-camera, though the Court may allow specified persons access.
The Court may use video links or screens for protection of victims and witnesses.
No person may publish or broadcast information about such proceedings without permission of the Court.

content.source: Inserted by S.7 of Fed. Act No. XXXVII of 2023

articles.title: Investigation into child sexual content referred to PTA

clauses.clause_text: FIA shall acquire information of child sexual abuse content referred to PTA or related organizations for investigation prior to its removal or blocking, whether a complaint has been filed or not.

content.source: Inserted by S.7 of Fed. Act No. XXXVII of 2023

articles.title: Expedited preservation and acquisition of data

clauses.clause_text: An authorized officer may require preservation of specific data for up to ninety days to prevent its loss or alteration, notifying the Court within 24 hours.
Court may extend the preservation period upon application if deemed necessary.
Service providers shall retain specified traffic data for at least one year and provide it upon Court-issued warrant.
Owners violating this provision shall be fined up to ten million rupees, or imprisoned up to six months for repeated offences.
Court may issue warrant to authorize officers to search, access, and seize data or devices relevant to an offence.
In urgent cases, authorized officers may act without a warrant but must notify the Court within 24 hours.

articles.title: Warrant for disclosure of content data

clauses.clause_text: Court may order disclosure of content data stored in an information system for criminal investigation purposes.
Warrants may be extended beyond seven days by Court order.
Authorized officers may inspect, copy, or access data, demand technical assistance, and require decryption for investigation.
Officers must act proportionately, maintain integrity, avoid disruption to unrelated systems, and preserve data secrecy.
Data seizure must use technical measures to preserve chain of custody; complete seizure is a last resort.
Seized data must remain confidential, and logs of all actions must be maintained.

articles.title: Dealing with seized data or information system

clauses.clause_text: Authorized officers must list all seized items and provide a copy to the owner or occupier.
Owners may request a forensic image of data upon payment of prescribed costs.
Court may restrict providing copies if it may prejudice investigation or criminal proceedings.
All costs for exercising rights under this section shall be borne by the requester.
PTA may remove or block access to information if necessary for national security, morality, decency, or prevention of offences under this Act.
Rules shall ensure safeguards, transparency, and oversight for such actions.
Appeal against PTA review decision lies before the High Court within thirty days.

articles.title: Limitation of liability of service providers

clauses.clause_text: Service providers are not liable unless they had actual knowledge and willful intent to facilitate offences.
No liability shall arise for actions done in good faith.
Service providers are not required to proactively monitor or filter user content.

articles.title: Real-time collection and recording of information

clauses.clause_text: Court may authorize designated agencies to collect or record information in real-time for criminal investigation, for not more than seven days.
Court may extend collection beyond seven days upon justified application.
Applications must specify the data sought, the offence involved, privacy safeguards, and necessity of collection.
The Federal Government shall establish or designate a forensic laboratory independent of the investigation agency for expert opinion and electronic evidence analysis.

Any person or authorized officer who discloses personal information without consent or lawful authority with intent to cause harm shall be punished with imprisonment up to three years or fine up to one million rupees or both.
Burden of proof of good faith lies upon the accused service provider or authorized officer.

The Federal Government may upon receipt of a request, through the designated agency under this Act, extend such cooperation to any foreign government including the government of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, 24 x 7 network, any foreign agency or any international organization or agency for the purposes of investigations or proceedings concerning offences related to information systems, electronic communication or data or for the collection of evidence in electronic form relating to an offence or obtaining expeditious preservation and disclosure of data by means of an information system or real-time collection of data associated with specified communications or interception of data under this Act.

The Federal Government may forward to a foreign government, 24x7 network, any foreign agency or any international agency or organization any information obtained from its own investigations if it considers that the disclosure of such information might assist the other government, agency or organization in initiating or carrying out investigations or proceedings concerning any offence under this Act.

The Federal Government shall require the foreign government, 24 x 7 network, any foreign agency or any international organization or agency to keep the information provided confidential and use it strictly for the purposes it is provided.
The Federal Government may, through the designated agency, send and answer requests for mutual assistance and ensure their execution or transmission to the authorities competent for their execution.
The Federal Government may refuse to accede to any request made by a foreign government, 24 x 7 network, any foreign agency or any international organization or agency, if:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: it is of the opinion that the request, if granted, would prejudice sovereignty, security, public order or other essential public interest of Pakistan;
the offence is regarded by the Federal Government as being of a political nature;

there are substantial grounds for believing that the request for assistance has been made for the purpose of prosecuting a person on account of that person’s race, sex, religion, nationality, ethnic origin or political opinions or that the person’s position may be prejudiced for any of those reasons;
the request relates to an offence the prosecution of which in the requesting State may be incompatible with the laws of Pakistan;

the assistance requested requires the Federal Government to carry out compulsory measures inconsistent with the laws or practices of Pakistan had the offence been the subject of investigation or prosecution under its own jurisdiction;
the request concerns an offence which may prejudice an ongoing investigation or trial or rights of citizens guaranteed under the Constitution.

clauses.clause_text: Where the Federal Government decides to provide the requested cooperation, the relevant requirements and safeguards provided under this Act and rules framed thereunder shall be followed.

The designated agency shall maintain a register of requests received from any foreign government, 24 x 7 network, any foreign agency or any international organization or agency under this Act and action taken thereon.

articles.title: Offences to be compoundable and non-cognizable

clauses.clause_text: All offences under this Act, except the offences under sections 10, 21 and 22 and abetment thereof, shall be non-cognizable, bailable and compoundable:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: Provided that offences under section 17 shall be cognizable by the investigation agency on a written complaint by the Authority.

clauses.clause_text: Offences under sections 10, 21, 22, 22A, 22B, 22C and abetment thereof shall be non-bailable, non-compoundable and cognizable by the investigation agency.

Complaint against the offences under sections 10, 21, 21A, 21B, 21C, 21D, 21E, 21F and abetment thereof may be lodged with concerned authorities by the complainant as defined under clause (viia) of section 2.

content.source: PEC2016.pdf, inserted by Federal Act No. XXXVII of 2023

clauses.clause_text: The Federal Government, in consultation with the Chief Justice of respective High Court, shall designate presiding officers of the Courts to try offences under this Act at such places as deemed necessary.

The Federal Government shall, in consultation with the Chief Justice of respective High Court, arrange for special training of the presiding officers of the Court to be conducted by an entity notified by the Federal Government for training on computer sciences, cyber forensics, electronic transactions and data protection.
Prosecution and trial of an offence under this Act committed by a minor shall be conducted under the Juvenile Justice System Ordinance, 2000 (XXII of 2000).
To the extent not inconsistent with this Act, the procedure laid down under the Code and the Qanoon-e-Shahadat, 1984 (P.O.No.X of 1984), shall be followed.

The Court may, in addition to award of any punishment including fine under this Act, make an order for payment of compensation to the victim for any damage or loss caused and the compensation so awarded shall be recoverable as arrears of land revenue:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: Provided that the compensation awarded by the Court shall not prejudice any right to a civil remedy for recovery of damages beyond the amount of compensation so awarded.

clauses.clause_text: The Government shall develop mechanism for the support of victims in collaboration with other agencies and civil society organizations.

content.source: PEC2016.pdf, inserted by Federal Act No. XXXVII of 2023

articles.title: Appointment of amicus curiae and seeking expert opinion

clauses.clause_text: The Court may appoint amicus curiae or seek independent expert opinion on any matter connected with a case pending before it.
An appeal against the final judgment or order of a Court shall, within thirty days from the date of provision of its certified copy free of cost, lie:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: to the High Court concerned against such judgment or order if passed by a court of sessions;
to the court of sessions concerned against such judgment or order if passed by a magistrate.

clauses.clause_text: The Federal Government or the Authority, as the case may be, may issue directives to be followed by the owners of the designated information systems or service providers in the interest of preventing any offence under this Act.

Any owner of the information system who is not a licensee of the Authority and violates the directives issued under sub-section (1) shall be guilty of an offence punishable, if committed for the first time, with fine which may extend to ten million rupees and upon any subsequent conviction shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to six months or with fine or with both:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: Provided that where the violation is committed by a licensee of the Authority, the same shall be deemed to be a violation of the terms and conditions of the license and shall be treated as such under the Pakistan Telecommunication (Re-organization) Act, 1996.

clauses.clause_text: The Federal Government may constitute one or more computer emergency response teams to respond to any threat against or attack on any critical infrastructure information systems or critical infrastructure data, or widespread attack on information systems in Pakistan.
A computer emergency response team constituted under sub-section (1) may comprise of technical experts of known expertise, officers of any intelligence agency or any sub-set thereof.

A computer emergency response team shall respond to a threat or attack without causing any undue hindrance or inconvenience to the use and access of the information system or data as may be prescribed.

articles.title: Relation of the Act with other laws

clauses.clause_text: The provisions of this Act shall have effect not in derogation of the Pakistan Penal Code, 1860 (Act XLV of 1860), the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898), the Qanoon-e-Shahadat, 1984 (P.O. No. X of 1984), the Protection of Pakistan Act, 2014 (X of 2014) and the Investigation for Fair Trial Act, 2013 (I of 2013).
Subject to sub-section (1), the provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any other law on the subject for the time being in force.

content.introductory_text: The Federal Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Act.

clauses.clause_text: The Federal Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out purposes of this Act.
Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing powers, such rules may specify:

sub_clauses.sub_clause_text: qualifications and trainings of the officers and staff of the investigation agency and prosecutors;
powers, functions and responsibilities of the investigation agency, its officers and prosecutors;
standard operating procedures of the investigation agency;
mode and manner in which record of investigation under this Act may be maintained;
manner to deal with the seized data, information system, device or other articles;
working of joint investigation teams;

requirements for seeking permission of the Authority to change, alter or re-programme unique device identifier of any communication equipment by any person for research or any other legitimate purpose;
procedure for seeking appropriate orders of the Authority for removal, destruction or blocking access to information under this Act;
constitution of computer emergency response team and the standard operating procedure to be adopted by such team;
appointment of designated agency having capability to collect real-time information;
manner of coordination between the investigation agency and other law enforcement and intelligence agencies including designated agency;
management and oversight of the forensic laboratory;
qualifications and trainings of the officers, experts and staff of the forensic laboratory;
powers, functions and responsibilities of the forensic laboratory, its officers, experts and staff;
standard operating procedures of the forensic laboratory to interact with the investigation agency;
manner of soliciting and extending international cooperation;
matters connected or ancillary thereto.

clauses.clause_text: If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Federal Government may, within two years of the commencement of this Act and by order published in the official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as may appear to be necessary for removing the difficulty.

The agency designated or established under section 29 of the Act shall submit a half-yearly report to both houses of the Parliament for consideration by the relevant Committee in camera, in respect of its activities, without disclosing identity information, in a manner as prescribed under this Act.

articles.title: Amendment of Electronic Transactions Ordinance, 2002 (LI of 2002) and pending proceedings

clauses.clause_text: Sections 36 and 37 of the Electronic Transactions Ordinance, 2002 (LI of 2002) are omitted.

Any action taken by or with the approval of the Authority or proceedings pending under the provisions of the Electronic Transactions Ordinance, 2002 (LI of 2002) repealed by sub-section (1), shall continue and be deemed to have been taken or initiated under this Act.
Nothing in this Act shall affect, limit or prejudice the duly authorized and lawful powers and functions of the institutions controlled by the Governments exercised and performed in good faith.
